<target_code>
Here is the code of not_found_page:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
not_found_page (const void *cls,
                const char *mime,
                struct Session *session,
                struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  struct MHD_Response *response;
  (void) cls;     /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) session; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  /* unsupported HTTP method */
  response =
    MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (strlen (NOT_FOUND_ERROR),
                                            (const void *) NOT_FOUND_ERROR);
  if (NULL == response)
    return MHD_NO;
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection,
                            MHD_HTTP_NOT_FOUND,
                            response);
  if (MHD_YES !=
      MHD_add_response_header (response,
                               MHD_HTTP_HEADER_CONTENT_ENCODING,
                               mime))
  {
    fprintf (stderr,
             "Failed to set content encoding header!\n");
  }
  MHD_destroy_response (response);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.

There are also no function-pointer invocations, no assignments of function pointers, and no data structures or callbacks passed in from this function that obviously contain references to not_found_page. The only places that could possibly lead to indirect recursion are calls into external/library functions; those specific call sites are listed above for investigation. All remaining fragments (variable declarations, (void) casts for unused parameters, return statements, and simple enum/struct usage) do not indicate direct or indirect self-calling behavior and therefore do not need to be investigated for Rule 17.2.
